matched.actualTitle: Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) in Registration Name Field
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same vulnerability: unsanitized user input from the registration name field is directly inserted into a Jinja2 template string without proper sanitization. The expected finding identifies the vulnerable code location (views.py lines 60-63), and the actual finding confirms SSTI exploitation through template injection in the registration flow with impact including remote code execution and server compromise. The actual finding provides detailed POC showing Jinja2 template syntax evaluation (e.g., {%if 1%}PWNED{%endif%}) confirming server-side template processing.

extra.title: Stored XSS in User Registration Name Field
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This is a complementary finding to the SSTI vulnerability. While the SSTI focuses on server-side template injection, this finding identifies that the same vulnerable input also results in Stored XSS via improper JavaScript escaping when the payload is output in a script tag. Not originally expected but represents an important separate attack vector (client-side execution via XSS vs server-side execution via SSTI).

extra.title: Stored XSS in Multi-Step Registration Flow - Step 1 Name Field
extra.assessment: Valid duplicate/variant discovery - This is essentially the same Stored XSS finding as above, documented separately with slightly different payload examples (<script>alert(1)</script> vs xsstest");alert('XSS');(")

extra.title: Django Debug Mode Enabled - Sensitive Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This finding identifies DEBUG = True enabled in production, exposing application structure, Django version, URL patterns, and filesystem paths. This was not in the original expected findings list but represents a significant security issue separate from the SSTI vulnerability.

extra.title: Missing Secure Flag on Session and CSRF Cookies
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This identifies missing Secure flag on sessionid and csrftoken cookies, preventing HTTPS-only transmission. While the sessionid has HttpOnly protection, this represents a separate cookie security issue not in the original expected findings.

extra.title: CSRF Vulnerability on Logout Endpoint - GET Request Not Protected
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This identifies that the logout endpoint accepts GET requests without CSRF protection, allowing forced logouts. This is a distinct vulnerability from the SSTI issue, focusing on state-changing operations via GET method bypass.

extra.title: Missing Brute Force Protection - Unlimited Login Attempts
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This identifies absence of rate limiting, account lockout, or brute force protection on the login endpoint. This is a separate authentication security issue not covered in the original expected findings.

extra.title: Missing Cache-Control Headers on Logout Response
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This identifies missing Cache-Control, Pragma, and Expires headers on the logout redirect response, potentially allowing cache poisoning attacks. A separate header security issue not in the original findings.

extra.title: Weak Cookie SameSite Attribute - Lax Instead of Strict
extra.location: Application-wide cookie configuration (CSRF and session cookies)
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This identifies SameSite=Lax instead of SameSite=Strict on cookies, allowing CSRF attacks on top-level navigations. A separate cookie security weakness complementary to the CSRF vulnerability on the GET logout endpoint.
